titlestmt.titleproper: Register to The Quincy Porter Papers
titlestmt.author:
Compiled by Susan Marchant
August 1976

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 00:03

did.abstract: Music, correspondence and other papers, photographs, and additional materials by and about the American composer Quincy Porter (1897-1966)

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The Papers are open to qualified researchers by appointment. There are no restricted materials in the collection. Please contact Please contact the Special Collections staff to schedule an appointment.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Quincy Porter Papers were established in the Music Library of Yale University by Lois Porter in 1972.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Quincy Porter Papers are the physical property of the Irving S. Gilmore Music Library of Yale University. Copyrights belong to the composers and authors, or their legal heirs and assigns.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: MSS 15, The Quincy Porter Papers in the Irving S. Gilmore Music Library of Yale University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: In 12 series as follows: I. Correspondence. II. Programs. III. Newspaper clippings. IV. Biographical & analytical notes V. Classroom materials. VI. Published articles and books. VII. Photographs. VIII. Medals. IX. Scrapbooks. X. Porter's works. XI. Works copied or arranged by Porter. XII. Manuscript & photocopy works of other composers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Quincy Porter Papers contain the manuscript scores and sketches of Porter's musical compositions, including 2 symphonies, 9 string quartets, and other major compositions and smaller pieces. The Papers also include music copied or arranged by Porter. The correspondence contains letters to and from Porter and other individuals, publishers, performing organizations, and schools and universities. Porter's life and work are further documented by: programs and newspaper clippings; published articles and books; photographs; medals; and scrapbooks.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Quincy Porter was born in New Haven, Connecticut in 1897. He attended Yale University as a student of Horatio Parker. After graduating from there his studies carried him to Paris, New York, and Cleveland, and his teachers included Vincent d'Indy and Ernest Bloch. As a composer and teacher himself, Porter held positions at the Cleveland Institute, Vassar College, and the New England Conservatory - where he became its director in 1942 - before returning to Yale in 1946 as professor of music. He concluded his professional career there, serving as Master of Pierson College and Battell Professor of Music Theory. He died in Bethany, Connecticut on November 12, 1966.
Included on his list of many honors are the Coolidge Medal (1943) and the Pulitzer Prize for musical composition, awarded in 1954 for his Concerto Concertante for two pianos and orchestra.

Porter was actively involved in musical activities on the national level, as a glance at the register which follows will point out. Included in this collection is a wealth of correspondence dealing with his involvement in the American Composers Alliance, the National Institute of Arts & Letters, the American Music Center, and many other organizations and societies which concerned themselves with the musical developments of this century. Porter also played a major role in the organization of the musical sessions held at the Yaddo grounds located in Saratoga Springs, New York, and the large body of Yaddo correspondence contained in this collection provides something of the flavor of the events there during the late '30s.

Music -- United States -- 20th Century

Songs
String quartets -- Scores and parts
Symphonies -- Scores

odd.head: General
odd.p: An attempt has been made to arrange the correspondence into logical subdivisions according to subject matter and content, so as to aid the researcher in dealing with the rather large number of items in this series. This manner of organization hopefully preserves much of Porter's own attitude toward his correspondence, as many of these subdivisions were already in existence in the collection as he left it. (The Pulitzer Prize congratulatory letters, for example, were completely intact as a unit.) Because of Porter's special association with Yale in the capacity of a college master as well as faculty member, category (I) has been created to include correspondence dealing specifically with Pierson College or the Yale School of Music. Also included here are letters of congratulation from outside the Yale comunity which were addressed to Porter upon his appointment as master.

Within the subject-oriented categories--such as (C) Concerning Publication--letters to and from Porter have been grouped together and listed alphabetically by the name of the company, organization, etc., while the letters in section A (general) have been subdivided into those written to Porter and those written by Porter.

Cross references: Cross references have been provided throughout the correspondence to assist the researcher in locating specific correspondence. It should be noted that references have not been provided for letters falling into two categories:

Since these categories contain letters from persons closely associated with Porter in his various musical activities, it would seem rather redundant to provide individual references for these sections.

(scrapbook): The indication (scrapbook) which appears after many entries in the register is an explanation of the fact that what appears in the correspondence files is a photocopy of the original, the original being found in one of the several scrapbooks (series IX). Information as to the specific location-including page number in scrapbook--of the original has been notated on each of the photocopies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains published biographical material as well as information on Porter's works which may have been used in formulating program notes, etc.

did.unittitle: Compositores de América, vol.4 (Pan American Union)
National Institute of Arts & Letters. Proceedings
Notes on Two Dances for Radio
Notes on Suite in C Minor
Notes on Sonata No. 2 for Violin and Piano
Notes on Quintet for Oboe and Strings
Analytical comments about Concerto Concertante, Symphony No. 1, Dance in 3-Time

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Notes used by Porter as a student and/or teacher are arranged in this series. Also included here are term papers and projects submitted by his students.

did.unittitle: Notebooks dating from years of study under Ernest Bloch

odd.head: General
odd.p: [i.e. Cleveland Institute or New England Conservatory]

did.unittitle: Notes, String Quartet Analysis class, Yale
Lists of grades, lists of assignments, notes on pupils
Diagrams, analysis of Well-Tempered Clavier Books I & II
Diagrams, analysis of Well-Tempered Clavier Books I & II
Diagrams, analysis of Well-Tempered Clavier Books I & II

odd.head: General
odd.p: This series includes periodical articles as well as Porter's published theoretical writings. Materials have been placed into two categories: those written by Porter and those of other authorship.

did.unittitle:
Outline for the Study of Fugue Writing
, pamphlet
"The Education of the American Composer," article in Musicology, vol. I, no. 1

A Study of l6th-Century Counterpoint
, 1st ed.

A Study of l6th-Century Counterpoint
, 2nd ed.

A Study of l6th-Century Counterpoint
, 3rd ed.
"Charles Ives 1874-1954," article by Leo Schrade. Yale Review, summer 1955
"The New Liberalism," article by Billy Jim Layton.Perspectives of New Music, vol. III, no.2 (spring/summer 1965)
"America in American Music," article by Philip Gordon. Common Ground, spring issue, 1947
"On Improving Violins," by Frederick A. Saunders & Carleen M. Hutchins. Violins and Violinists Magazine, vol. 13, nos. 7/8, Nov-Dec 1952
"A Study of Tap Tones," by Hutchins, Hopping, Saunders. The Strad, Aug-Sep 1958
"Subharmonics and Plate Tap Tones in Violin Acoustics," by Hutchins, Hopping, Saunders. Journal of the Acoustical Society of America, vol. 32, no. 11, Nov 1960
"Violins Old and New: An Experimental Study," by F.A. Saunders. Sound, vol, 1, no. 4 Jul-Aug 1962
"The Physics of Violins," by Carleen Hutchins. Scientific American, Nov 1962
"Some Thoughts on the Requirements of a Good Varnish," by Robert E. Fryxell. The Strad, Feb 1965

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The main body of this small group of photographs concerns itself with associates of Porter during his Cleveland years. Also present are several scenes from the Music Hut, an endeavor and by-product of Porter's summer vacations.

did.unittitle: Porter with Mr. and Mrs. Jean Binet
Medal, presented by XIth Olympiade, Berlin

odd.head: General
odd.p: These scrapbooks are full of many interesting items: clippings, programs, letters, other memorabilia. Please note that all correspondence contained in these scrapbooks has been photocopied and filed alphabetically within the correspondence series.
The numbering of Scrapbooks is Porter's numbering.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Porter's works have been listed chronologically according to date of composition. Concluding the series are several folders of unidentified sketches as well as a set of index cards which contain information about the works, including dates of performance (notations made by Porter).
For index cards containing data on Porter works, see folder 159.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These works have been listed alphabetically by composer. The large majority of them are photocopies of manuscripts. Inscriptions or dedications from the composers which appear on the scores have been noted in the register.
